slides.text: BIRDS: Over 10,000 species, found on every continent. Key features: FEATHERS (unique to birds — for flight, insulation, and display), HOLLOW BONES (lightweight for flight), BEAK instead of teeth (lighter), WARM-BLOODED (maintain constant body temperature), lay HARD-SHELLED EGGS, have a highly efficient respiratory system with air sacs.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is all about birds! It tells us they're super diverse, with tons of different kinds all over the world. The slide highlights their special features: feathers for flying and staying warm, bones that are hollow to make them light, beaks instead of heavy teeth, and the fact that they can keep their bodies at a steady temperature, just like us. They also lay eggs with hard shells.

slides.text: How do birds fly? The combination of: (1) Lightweight hollow bones. (2) Powerful chest muscles (the breast muscles can be 25% of body weight). (3) Wing shape creates LIFT (same principle as airplane wings). (4) Feathers provide surface area and control. Not all birds fly — penguins swim, ostriches run. Flight is an adaptation, not a requirement for being a bird.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, how do these awesome creatures actually fly? This slide breaks it down for us. It's a combo of their light, hollow bones, super strong chest muscles for flapping, and the special shape of their wings that helps them catch the air, kind of like an airplane. Feathers are also key for giving them control and lift, but remember, not all birds fly – some, like penguins, are amazing swimmers instead!

slides.text: MAMMALS: About 6,400 species. Key features: HAIR or FUR (for insulation), MAMMARY GLANDS (produce milk to feed young), WARM-BLOODED, most give LIVE BIRTH (except monotremes: platypus, echidna), larger brain relative to body size than other vertebrates. Mammals live everywhere: land (elephants), sea (whales), air (bats), underground (moles).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at mammals, which includes us! The slide points out that mammals have hair or fur to keep them warm, and the special thing called mammary glands that produce milk to feed their babies. Like birds, they are warm-blooded, and most give birth to live young, though there are a few exceptions like the platypus. Mammals are everywhere, from deep in the ocean to high in the sky thanks to bats.

slides.text: Why is being WARM-BLOODED (endothermic) important? It means you can be active in any temperature. Cold-blooded animals slow down in cold weather — a lizard on a cold morning cannot run from predators. Warm-blooded animals can hunt, flee, and function in any conditions. The cost: we need MUCH more food (about 10x more than a same-sized reptile) to fuel our internal furnace.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really important point: why is being warm-blooded so cool? It means you can be active no matter what the weather is like. Unlike cold-blooded animals that have to hide when it's chilly, warm-blooded animals can run, hunt, and play all the time. The trade-off is that we need a lot more food to keep that internal furnace going, but being able to be active anytime is a huge advantage.

slides.prompt: Create a MASTER COMPARISON CHART of all 5 vertebrate classes with these columns: Class, Body Covering, Breathing, Temperature, Reproduction, Habitat, Number of Species, Example. Then answer: (1) Which class has the most species? (2) Which class are humans in? List 5 characteristics that prove it. (3) Is a penguin a bird or a mammal? How do you know? (4) Is a whale a fish or a mammal? Explain. (5) Which vertebrate class do you think is most 'successful' and why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we get to be super scientists and put everything together! You're going to create a big chart comparing all five types of animals we've learned about – fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals – looking at things like what covers their bodies, how they breathe, and how they reproduce. Then, you'll answer some fun questions, like which animal group has the most types, and whether a penguin is more like a bird or a mammal.

slides.text: From fish to mammals, vertebrates represent over 500 million years of evolution. Each class developed adaptations for its environment — gills for water, lungs for air, feathers for flight, fur for warmth. Understanding these relationships helps us see the unity and diversity of life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe key characteristics of all 5 vertebrate classes and compare them across multiple categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've covered so much ground, from the earliest fish to the amazing mammals! This last slide reminds us that every animal group has developed special tricks, called adaptations, to survive in its own home, whether that's breathing underwater with gills or flying through the air with feathers. It's pretty incredible to see how life has changed and diversified over millions of years.

parent_notes: This lesson completes the vertebrate survey. The master comparison chart is a valuable reference for the rest of the biology unit. The tricky classification questions (Is a penguin a bird? Is a whale a mammal?) teach children to classify based on CHARACTERISTICS rather than superficial appearance. The 'which class is most successful' question has no right answer but sparks excellent critical thinking. If you have pets, identify their class and discuss their specific adaptations. Bird watching is a wonderful extension activity that combines science and outdoor time.

title: Tapestry Art — The Bayeux Tapestry and Visual Storytelling
description: Students study the Bayeux Tapestry as an example of medieval visual storytelling, learn about the craft of tapestry making, and create their own narrative tapestry strip telling a story from history or their own life.
instructions:
1. Introduce the Bayeux Tapestry: 230 feet long, tells the story of the Norman Conquest (1066).
2. Examine sections: how the story unfolds in sequential panels.
3. Discuss tapestry as a medium: embroidery on linen, years to create.
4. Analyze the visual storytelling techniques: figures, borders, Latin text.
5. Students choose a story to tell in tapestry form.
6. Create a long narrative strip with sequential scenes.
7. Add borders with decorative elements.
8. Present the tapestry, narrating the story it tells.
materials_needed: Long strip of paper (or taped sheets)

slides.heading: Tapestry Art
slides.subheading: The Bayeux Tapestry and Visual Storytelling
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our project! We're going to learn all about something called the Bayeux Tapestry, which is basically a super old, super long picture story, and then we'll get to make our own picture stories. Think of it like a medieval comic strip that tells a big historical event.

items: Long paper strip (tape sheets together for at least 3 feet)
slides.setup_instructions: Tape several sheets of paper together to create a long strip at least 3 feet long and about 8 inches tall. Look up images of the Bayeux Tapestry online.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide tells us what we need to gather for our art project. We need a really long strip of paper – you'll tape some sheets together to make it at least 3 feet long. Then grab your colored pencils or markers, a regular pencil, a ruler, and look up pictures of the Bayeux Tapestry online so you can see what it looks like.

slides.text: The Bayeux Tapestry is one of the world's greatest works of narrative art. Created around 1070 CE, it is actually an embroidery (not a woven tapestry) on linen cloth, measuring 230 feet long and 20 inches tall. It tells the story of the Norman Conquest of England in 1066 through 58 scenes, like a medieval comic strip.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn about the original Bayeux Tapestry. Imagine a giant strip of cloth, 230 feet long, that tells the whole story of a big battle called the Norman Conquest from way back in 1066. It's like a history book told entirely with pictures stitched onto fabric, with each part showing the next thing that happened.

slides.text: Study how it works: figures are shown in profile (side view), arranged left to right in chronological order. A top border and bottom border feature animals, symbols, and scenes of daily life. Brief Latin text identifies key characters and events. The flat, stylized figures convey action clearly even from a distance.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at *how* the Bayeux Tapestry tells its story. See how the people are shown from the side, like in a profile? That's a common trick in this kind of art to make the action clear. It also has fancy borders with animals and symbols, and little bits of writing to explain things, all arranged so you read it from left to right, just like a book.

slides.text: Choose your story. It can be: (a) A historical event you have studied (the Fall of Rome, a Viking voyage, the building of a castle). (b) A personal narrative (your family's story, a memorable trip, a year of your life). (c) A retelling of a story you love. Plan at least 6 sequential scenes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative! This step is all about picking the story *you* want to tell with your own tapestry. You could choose a historical event you've learned about, maybe something from your own life like a cool trip, or even retell a story you already love. The main thing is to plan out at least six different moments or scenes that happen one after another.

slides.text: Create your tapestry: (1) Divide your strip into panels with pencil lines. (2) Sketch figures in a flat, medieval style (profile views, simple shapes). (3) Add a decorative top and bottom border. (4) Add brief text labels for each scene. (5) Color with flat, bold colors (medieval tapestries used limited palettes: blues, reds, greens, yellows, black).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part: making your tapestry! First, use your ruler and pencil to divide your long paper strip into sections for each scene. Then, sketch out your pictures in that simple, side-view style we saw, add some cool borders at the top and bottom, and write short labels for each scene. Finally, color it in using bright, bold colors, just like they did back then.

slides.prompt: Complete your narrative tapestry strip. Include: at least 6 sequential scenes, figures in medieval flat style, decorative borders above and below, text labels identifying scenes, and consistent color scheme. When finished, display the tapestry and narrate the story to someone, pointing to each scene as you tell it — just as a medieval storyteller might have done.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to finish up your amazing tapestry! Make sure you have at least six scenes showing your story in order, with those cool medieval-style drawings and borders. Add your labels and use a consistent set of colors throughout. Once it's all done, you'll get to show it off and tell the story just like a real medieval storyteller would, pointing to each part as you go.

slides.text: The Bayeux Tapestry has survived nearly 1,000 years and is still telling its story. Your tapestry tells YOUR story. Visual storytelling — telling stories through images — predates writing and continues today in comics, graphic novels, and film. You are part of an ancient tradition.
slides.mastery_check: Did the student create a narrative tapestry strip with sequential scenes, medieval-inspired artistic style, and clear visual storytelling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you just created your very own piece of visual storytelling, just like the people who made the Bayeux Tapestry almost a thousand years ago! You've learned how images can tell a whole story, and you've done a fantastic job with your sequential scenes, medieval style, and borders. You're officially part of an awesome, ancient art tradition!

parent_notes: The Bayeux Tapestry is a masterpiece of narrative art and an important historical document. Looking at it online is essential for this project. The tapestry-making process connects art, history, and storytelling. Children love the comic-strip-like format. The presentation component (narrating while pointing) is a public speaking exercise. If your child enjoys this, the tapestry can be extended over time to tell more of the story. The project can also be done with fabric and embroidery for a more authentic experience.
